Dr. Swallow taught for many years as a mathematics teacher focused on engaged and active learning by supporting the connection of knowledge with application and creativity. Her current teaching and research centers on supporting pre-service teachers and in-service graduate-level educators in developing, and engaging with, innovative teaching practices that support active, learner-driven environments, and effective technology integration.

Merit “Buzz” Bean joins the UMF staff after coaching both the Alpine and Nordic teams at Mt. Abram High School for more than 30 years, where he has always enjoyed a successful teaching career. Bean’s teams have won numerous Conference and State Championships.

He has been the President of the Maine Ski Coaches Association for more than 30 years and served as the liaison to the Maine Principals Association Ski Committee. Bean was also involved in the formation of the New England Nordic Ski Association and served as head of the Junior Committee, which led him to be a part of the Athlete Development Committee.

Professor Johnson teaches courses in American literature, film studies, multicultural literature, and African American literature. Recent courses include African American Literature and Culture, Popular Genres, The Splendid Drunken Twenties, and A History of the Horror Film. He also claims to be the English Department’s resident expert on surviving the Zombie Apocalypse. His book publications include “Can’t Stand Still: Taylor Gordon and the Harlem Renaissance,” “A Black Woman’s West: The Life of Rose B. Gordon,” and “Speculative Wests: Popular Representations of a Region and a Genre.” He is also a co-editor of two anthologies of criticism: “Weird Westerns: Race, Gender, Genre,” and “Hell-Bent for Leather: Sex and Sexuality in the Weird Western.”

Professor Schoeppner studies the history of race, migration, and law, especially in the United States. He is currently working on his second book, a history of the invention of illegal immigration. His courses include the American Revolution, Civil War and Reconstruction, and American Legal History, among others. He also teaches courses in the Honors Program, most of which explore the representation of history in film, video games, and commemoration ceremonies. When not cheering on his Florida Gators or Chelsea Football Club, he enjoys playing volleyball, skiing, playing chess, and traveling.

Dr. Beck coordinates the Learning Commons, a space dedicated to fostering student success through peer tutoring and academic coaching. She believes the right to an education is as vital for survival today as the right to common land once was, a conviction rooted in her doctoral research on the historic loss of these rights in England. Guided by the principle that learning is a process of growth and self-discovery, she hires, trains, and mentors a staff of 50 student employees, loving to watch them and those they tutor flourish. Away from work, Dr. Beck keeps her own New England traditions alive. She’s a passionate gardener, a nature poet, an avid contradancer, and an unpolished fiddle player. Her dog, Scout, tolerates the music but loves walking rural lanes with her best.

Dr. Krueger teaches courses in English, gender studies, monster studies, and 18th-century literature. They specialize in Jane Austen and William Shakespeare. They have edited a book: Transatlantic Women Travelers, 1688-1843. They have published many essays on Austen and other subjects and are writing a book: Jane Austen’s Monsters.

Molly Wilkie became the UMF Head coach of Women’s Soccer in 2008. She also coached the UMF Women’s Lacrosse program through the 2015 season and qualified for the North Atlantic Conference postseason seven times.

She was named the North Atlantic Conference Women’s Soccer Coach of the Year in 2010, after leading the UMF Beavers to a 6-1-0 conference record. Under her helm, UMF Women’s Soccer athletes have captured 33 All-NAC awards and UMF junior Kayla Tuttle was named an NSCAA All-New England Region selection. The 2012 squad posted a double-digit win total for the first time since 2007, and advanced to the NAC Tournament semifinals for the fourth time in five seasons. In 2013, Wilkie coached the NAC women’s soccer player of the year, Kayla Tuttle.

From 2013-2019, Willkie’s teams have compiled a 35-21-4 record during conference games. She led the 2018 team to a 5-2 Conference record and won the NAC Championship. The following year, her team finished with a 5-2-1 conference record and were the 2019 NAC runners-up.

Wilkie is a former Women’s Soccer player at UMF and played for the Beavers in 2004 and 2005. A starter in the backfield, Wilkie appeared in 40 games over two seasons with three goals and three assists. A leader on and off the field, Wilkie was captain of the 2005 team and named to the All-North Atlantic Conference Second and the NAC All-Tournament Team.

Wilkie transferred to UMF from the University of Southern Maine where she was an All-Little East Conference First Team and All-New England First Team choice in 2000 and All-LEC Second Team in 2001.

As a therapist, teacher, and researcher, Natasha Lekes is passionate about the role that psychology can play in helping people to live more satisfying and fulfilling lives. Her practice as a psychologist has included individual counseling, couples therapy, and sex therapy. She feels privileged to guide students in exploring questions on how mental disorder is defined and treated, views on death and dying, and approaches to mental health and well-being. Dr. Lekes’ research has examined the relationship between values and happiness. Her work is most recently published in the Journal of Positive Psychology .

Women’s Basketball Coach Nate Carson began coaching with the UMF Men’s program in the 2014-2015 season, learning under the tutelage of legendary UMF coaches Dick Meader and Jim Bessey. Carson has been a part of the program ever since.

Before coaching, Carson was a member of the UMF Men’s Basketball program from 2010 to 2014. A three-year starter, Carson helped his team host the North Atlantic Conference (NAC) Tournament as well as contributing to a 21-6 record in his junior year. In his senior year, he helped the Beavers make it to the NAC Championship.

Nicholas Koban has been a mathematics professor at UMF since 2006, and he teaches a wide variety of courses in the mathematics major as well as for other disciplines. He is interested in studying sets on which algebra can be performed (not necessarily sets of numbers), but uses geometry to study these algebraic sets instead of algebra. Each year he hires a research assistant to help with studying these algebraic objects. These students will usually assist in his research projects along with working on their own individual project.

Professor Nicole Kellett is originally from Nebraska, but has moved throughout much of the country before landing in Maine. She teaches courses in environmental justice, medical anthropology, gender, Latin America, methods, and theory, among others. Her research centers primarily on economic development, war and reconciliation in Peru; women and the criminal legal system in the United States; and HIV/AIDS-related stigma in Uganda. Outside of work, Professor Nicole Kellett enjoys adventuring in the outdoors with family and friends with a perpetual goal of becoming more musical.

Noel Wilson is the Director of Field Services. He holds an M. Ed in Educational Leadership and Administration from Regis University. He also holds a B.A. in Psychology and a B.S. in Early Childhood Education. Noel taught for many years at the elementary school level, as well as serving as a Building Administrator. Noel’s passions are in the areas of Early Literacy Development, Mindfulness Integration and Leadership Development.

Paloma Shelton graduated Magna cum laude in the University of Maine at Farmington Class of 2025 as a university honors scholar with a double major in Outdoor Recreation Business Administration and a self-designed major in Sustainability and Artificial Intelligence. Paloma was a varsity athlete on the alpine ski team and served as captain for two seasons. Her honors thesis, Redefining Readiness: Higher Education’s Role in an AI World , led to strategic work with both UMF and the University of Maine System on AI implementation in higher education. Next for Paloma is living in New York City and working at Umbrage, a craft-based digital studio building end-to-end digital products.

Patty Gordon has lived in Maine for 35 years and was a middle school teacher for most of them before coming to UMF. She teaches courses in Education and advises Elementary Education majors. Patty instructs/supervises field courses for all Education majors including Practicum, Advanced Practicum and Student Teaching. When she’s not working, Patty enjoys being outdoors hiking, swimming, xc skiing, gardening and walking in the woods with family and friends. She likes learning new things, and next on her list is learning to play the cello.

Dr. Williams teaches undergraduate and graduate courses in early childhood education across face-to-face, online, and hybrid modalities. Her research and grants focus on practical solutions to educational challenges, particularly through university-community collaborations, informed by her interdisciplinary Ph.D. in Applied Child Development. She is a native of Western New York and was a first-generation college student. In her spare time she enjoys volunteering in her community, serving on the board of a local children’s play museum and designing exhibits.

Paul Gies likes to say that while he wasn’t actually born on Pluto, his home asteroid was destroyed by Zerkons. He likes to say that after receiving his English degree from Iowa, he applied for graduate school in English, but he put down the wrong code number and ended up in mathematics. Every time he went to change majors, the line was too long, so Gies wound up staying in math. It’s easier than trying to explain how a child of a historian parents, born in Connecticut, wound up with a BA in English from Iowa and a math PhD from Illinois, and found a job teaching in Maine. In truth, the job announcement from UMF looked amazing; the job turned out to be even better than it had looked; and once here, he realized he was in the right place to teach, to mentor students, and to write.

Dr. Peter Hardy was born in the month of December, in the little town of Bethlehem...Pennsylvania. Since then he has climbed Mt. Kenya on Christmas, slapped a seal in New Zealand, narrated a novel in Maine, snorkeled with sharks in Belize, betrothed a bride in Beijing, rode rapids in Bali, deferred a diploma in Mexico, rescued a rhesus in Rwanda, serenaded a street corner in Prague, and clutched a crocodile in Thailand. Exactly one of those exploits is untrue. He is currently teaching mathematics and zen, putting poetry to music and creating a sustainable lifestyle while living the dream with his family on Rainbow Farm in West Farmington.

Dr. Rachel Hovel is an aquatic ecologist who studies fishes and invertebrates across a range of freshwater habitats. Major themes of her research include species interactions, the timing of ecological events, and biodiversity of species and life histories. In particular, she is interested in how changes to freshwater environments–especially climate change–influence aquatic organisms and ecosystems. Rachel’s work takes place in Alaska, the Canadian Arctic, and the lakes of Maine. Visit her website for more information: rachelhovel.wordpress.com

Rebecca joined the Athletics Staff in 2021 and became the ACSUM union representative for the Farmington campus in 2023. While not particularly athletic herself, she does enjoy watching student athletes excel in their chosen sport(s). GO BEAVERS!
Renee has been a member of the Merrill Center team since January of 2022. She enjoys spending time with family, exploring trails with her two dogs, and curling up with a good book.

Dr. Jamison is interested in human motivation, especially as it relates to students and school. She has investigated academic motivation in adolescents and college students. She regularly teaches Child and Adolescent Development, as well as several core Psychology courses. Outside of work, Dr. Jamison loves to hang out with her husband and young daughter.

Robert Hollis, a former three-year captain for the University of Maine at Farmington cross country and track & field teams, rejoined the Beavers as an assistant coach in October 2021.

Hollis was a standout distance runner for the Beavers during his time at UMF. He was named the North Atlantic Conference (NAC) Runner of the Year in 2015 and was named first-team All-Conference three times from 2015 to 2017. Hollis still holds records for Track and Field in the 1500m, 5k, and 10k events.

Recently he competed in the 2021 Maine Marathon and finished in eighth place with a time of 2:37:58.

Hollis is a 2018 graduate of UMaine-Farmington with a degree in community health education. He is currently a personal endurance coach, helping athletes prepare for races from 5k up to a full marathon.
titles: Head Men's and Women's Cross Country Coach

biography: I work on the front line of the Merrill Center helping students with Records & Registration and Student Accounts. In my spare time I love to garden, do crafts, and spend time with my three grandsons.

Professor Beaulieu is a Maine native and UMF alumnus (Class of 1991). Her primary responsibility at UMF is supervising education students in their field experiences. Outside of work, she enjoys reading, quilting, knitting, and walking with her golden retriever, Bruce.

Sarah is a Licensed Clinical Social Worker, UMF alum (’06), and serves as the Director of UMF’s Mental Health & Counseling Services. In addition to her MSW, Sarah has a Master’s in Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies, both from The Ohio State University. She is also President of The Eating Disorders Association of Maine. Outside of the office, Sarah is passionate about performing in community theater and spoiling her numerous pets.

Sarah graduated from UMF in 2006, with a B.A. in Women’s Studies, and a minor in 
Psychology. After graduation, Sarah attended The Ohio State University, where she received an 
M.A. in Women’s, Gender, and Sexuality Studies, and a Master’s in Clinical Social Work. While 
at OSU, Sarah also taught courses in the Dept of Women’s Studies and completed an internship 
in the counseling center. Prior to returning to UMF, Sarah worked as a therapist in Lewiston and 
Rumford, Maine. Sarah works with a wide variety of concerns, including trauma, anxiety, eating 
disorders/body image, sexuality, gender, life events/transitions, race/ethnicity, and academic 
challenges.

Email umfcounseling@maine.edu or call 207-778-7034 during open hours to schedule an 
appointment. All students with billable insurance can have up to three visits per semester 
without a co-pay charge. After three visits, you will be charged the co-pay amount associated 
with your insurance plan. Students with insurance that we cannot bill or who fail to present a 
health insurance card will be charged $20 for every visit. Students who have not met their annual 
insurance deductible or if your insurance company denies a submitted claim, will be charged $20 
for the office visit. Students never have to pay up-front for services; they may have any charges 
added to their student account.

Accountability 
Any dissatisfaction or complaints may be registered by contacting Any dissatisfaction or 
complaints may be registered by contacting Christine Wilson, Vice President of Student Affairs 
and Enrollment Management or the State Board of Social Worker Licensure, 35 State House 
Station Augusta, (207) 624-8623.

Sarah fell in love with holography as a medium for art as an undergraduate at Lake Forest College. At UT Austin she explored kabuki-inspired 18th-century Japanese courtesan prints for her MA thesis, then returned to holography for her doctoral dissertation. Because there was a wonderful Japanese film series featuring Ozu and other Japanese greats at Hogg Auditorium across those years–starring Austin’s local community of adorable Mexican Freetail bats flapping across the screen at critically interesting and emotionally charged moments–she became interested in the phenomenology of cinematic experience and other aspects of film theory, leading her back to the strange place of the viewer in different forms of holography and contemporary art. Sarah wants her students to explore connections across disciplines and interests. No bats required, though there are scholarly Little Brown bats on the 4th floor of Merrill happy to collaborate!

Sarah A. Sloane is an avian behavioral ecologist specializing in the evolution of complex social systems, primarily cooperative breeding systems. Her current research focuses on the complex social system of the American Bushtit (Psaltriparus minimus) in Portland, Oregon. This year marks the 39th year Sarah has been studying bushtits, beginning in 1986 in southwestern Arizona for 25 years, with a brief foray into Washington State before migrating to Portland, Oregon in 2016. At UMF, Sarah greatly enjoys teaching behavioral ecology at all levels and has a special interest in mentoring undergraduate students by including them in her own research as well as guiding them in their own. Outside of work she enjoys hiking, making music, painting, and spending time with her adorable grandson.

Professor Erb teaches courses on international relations, American foreign policy and political philosophy. His research interests include German foreign policy and the European Union. Professor Erb is fluent in German and working hard to learn Italian. He was born in Minnesota and grew up in South Dakota, but has been at UMF since 1995.

Coach Cabaniss is a UMF alum ‘17 (Applied Mathematics and Secondary Education) and was a cofounder of the UMF Track & Field program during his time at UMF. After attending Smith College for a masters in Exercise and Sport Studies, he returned to UMF to takeover the program, and helped lead the Beavers to their first NAC Track titles in program history (‘25). He lives in Pittsfield with his wife and two golden retrievers. Go Beavers!

Dr. Shannon Larsen was born and raised near Toronto, Canada. She received her B.A. from Middlebury College, VT. She majored in Russian and minored in both French and Elementary Education. After spending a year teaching 2nd grade in Cali, Colombia, Dr. Larsen returned to the United States. She received her Ed. M from Harvard Graduate School of Education where she studied International Education. Dr. Larsen spent several years as a 5th grade teacher in a town north of Boston and eventually became the district’s elementary mathematics coach. She also spent one year teaching 7th grade math. In 2012, Dr. Larsen graduated from the University of Toronto with a Ph.D in Curriculum, Teaching, and Learning. Her research focuses on professional learning for elementary school teachers and collaborative classroom practices. In her free time, she loves to travel, read, and spend time with friends and family.

Sheena Bunnell teaches courses in Business Economics with an emphasis on application in applied quantitative research, healthcare, consumer trends, and current economic events. Her classes are interactive and engage students in real world business applications that focus on international and domestic markets. Business goes beyond borders and understanding global interdependence is vital for future enterepreneurs and financiers whether they are working for their own small business or a Fortune 500 company . For example, in Consumer Behavior students learn the importance of business to consumer relations and engage in the understanding of the U.S. consumer as they navigate the $16 Trillion U.S. economy. She works collaboratively with students on healthcare research projects and supervises student internships. Her passion for teaching is like her passion for gardening where it is very fulfilling to watch a student grow and blossom.

Shelley joined the UMF community in 2017. She is a Maine native who brought vast knowledge in adolescent and young adult medicine to her position. Her background includes experience working for the State of Maine Bureau of Health, leadership positions at Maine Medical Association and Maine Ambulatory Care Coalition, and experience providing rural primary health care and school based health care at various middle and high schools in central Maine. Shelley delivers competent and compassionate health care and education with a holistic approach. She focuses on individualized assessment of physical, psychological, and social dimensions for effective implementation of specialized plans of care.

Stan has been in the theater his entire adult life, even when working in other industries. After earning his BA as a double major in English and theater from Providence College he free-lanced extensively in Providence, RI with companies such as 2nd Story Theatre, Trinity Rep, and Opera RI. He was the resident designer/TD for the critically acclaimed Wickenden Gate Theatre for three seasons. Other regional theaters that he designed worked with include Triangle Theater of Boston, Goodspeed Opera House and Long Wharf Theatre in Connecticut. He has designed for The Public Theatre in Lewiston, Maine, Community Little Theater in Auburn and was a co-founder, resident designer/TD, and occasional actor in the multiple New England Theater Conference Moss Hart award winning Out of the Box Theater Company in Lewiston, ME. He has been the Resident Designer/TD of University of Maine-Farmington’s Alumni Theater and Emery Community Art Center since 2011.

Stephen Grandchamp teaches courses in the digital humanities and British literature. He also is the Co-Director of the New Commons Project and Manager of the Digital Humanities Lab. His current book project, Accounting for Failure: Arrested Development and the British Bildungsroman, 1805-1891 , examines failure as a counterpoint to pervasive notions of success and development across nineteenth-century narrative genres. His research also includes bibliometric analysis of literary texts and the integration of streaming media into the literature classroom.

Steven Pane’s career as a pianist and conductor emerges out of his life-long interest in the interdisciplinary study and performance of music. At UMF his work often involves collaborations such as the Celestial Emporium with poet Jeff Thompson and artist Dawn Nye; Intertextuality, Bakhtin, and Ives’s Concord Sonata with Tiane Donahue; or Bach’s Goldberg Variations and Stories with author Pat O’Donnell. Most recently, Pane gave the American premier of Ana-Maria Avram’s Musique pour Mallarme, at Harvard and UMF in 2010, and shares Avram and her partner Iancu Dumitrescu’s interest in phenomenology and music. Dr. Pane has performed at universities and in major halls throughout the country including the Academy of Music in Philadelphia, Aaron Davis Hall in New York City, Davies Hall in San Francisco, and the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts.

Originally from the San Francisco Bay Area, Dr. Steven Quackenbush completed his Ph.D. in social-personality psychology at Kansas State University in 1996. As a UMF faculty member, Dr. Quackenbush has taught a broad range of courses, including General Psychology (PSY 101), Adulthood and Aging (PSY 226), and Cognitive Psychology (PSY 314). His scholarly interests include the history of psychology and narrative approaches to the study of lifespan personality development. Dr. Quackenbush’s recent publications have explored issues relevant to the narrative structure of personal identity as well as the general problem of theoretical unification in the social sciences. Of his various accomplishments, Dr. Quackenbush is especially proud of his long track record of involving undergraduate students in original research.

Dr. Timothy Breton is a fish physiologist with expertise in reproductive development and applications to fisheries and aquaculture (fish farming). His research efforts have focused on understanding reproduction in several commercially important species, including Atlantic cod, black sea bass, summer flounder, and alewives. Dr. Breton also utilizes many modern molecular techniques to understand egg development, sex change, and sex differentiation in fishes, including quantitative PCR (qPCR) and genomics approaches. He has interests in all things related to fish or molecular biology, and is always looking to apply modern genetic techniques to new ecological or physiological questions.

Victoria graduated from the University of Pittsburgh with a bachelor’s degree in English Writing. After years of outdoor and local newspaper adventures out west, she earned her master’s degree in Magazine Journalism from Columbia University. She has worked as a national affairs correspondent for Newsweek, a senior editor at Working Mother, and is a longtime contributor to national media outlets. For the past several years, she has specialized in strategic marketing and thought leadership for start-ups and Fortune 100 companies.

These days, Victoria lives with the younger of her two sons, an alpine racer at Carrabassett Valley Academy, in a charming but drafty log cabin in Wyman. She loves cooking (and eating) with friends and family, making and fixing things, and going places —especially outdoors.

Professor Harper is a Maine native and teaches courses in microeconomics, finance and environmental economics. Her most recent research interests include non-market valuation, agriculture and food and sustainability. Outside of work, Professor Harper enjoys running, hiking and chauffeuring her children to their various sporting events. She is currently attempting to learn to ski, she hopes to one day complete an intermediate trail without injury.
